descript.supplinf:
Snow cover is a sedimentary ice deposit formed from precipitation that is a loose and porous aggregate of crystals and crystal fragments. Snow cover typically accumulates andremains on the earth's surface when air temperatures near the ground are below freezing. The snow covers of the continents are influenced by geographical zones, relief, and atmospheric circulation.
Snow cover is a specific part of the global water exchange cycle that stores water for many months. It is important for vegetation and wildlife, and it greatly affects human life and economic activity.
The maps show the mean annual duration of snow cover. Snow cover duration is the period that begins with the establishment of snow cover and ends when it is completely melted. Snow cover is said to be stable in areas where snow lies for at least one month during more than a half of all winters. It is said to be stable of long duration where snow lies for four or more months each year. Permanent snow cover occurs where snow falls throughout the year and does not melt completely during the summer.

procstep.procdesc:
Duration of snow cover was calculated using the observations of meteorological and snowmeasuring stations and posts. In mountains, stations are usually located in the lower parts. Therefore, snow characteristics in high mountains were indirectly determined based on other characteristics. The main factors determining the number of days with snow cover are the altitude of the terrain, maximum snow reserves, and latitude (for large areas). Other characteristics were also taken into account, including the direction of macroslopes in relation to moisture-bearing winds, distance from main moisture sources, and the altitude of a firn line.
The larger-scale maps from the Atlas of Snow and Ice Resources of the World (prepared for publication) were used. The isolines were considerably generalized according to mapping conventions.
